passages.text: Appliances: Labor Day 2025: Pricing Update
WHR 12m Price Target: \(\) 107.00\(Price:\) \ \(93.15\) Upside: \(14.9\%\)

Net Pricing Steady Despite Weak Demand: To better assess the competitive environment around Labor Day, we scanned appliance pricing across three retailers and five major manufacturers. Overall, results reflect continued discipline with net industry price up 223bps YOY vs +354bps at Fourth of July, as manufacturers look to mitigate the impact of tariffs and rising input costs. More specifically, we note discounts declined 102bps vs Fourth of July to \(24\%\) , below the 202bps average for the last couple of years, but rose 150bps YOY. We found a 496bps delta between producers, with Samsung the most promotional at \(27\%\) while Electrolux was the least at \(22\%\) , down 69bps YOY. In our view, the YOY increase in promotions comes as demand remains anemic while producers look to raise list prices to offset inflation and maintain margins. By category, promotions were led by more discretionary products with ranges at \(28\%\) as larger remodeling projects remain depressed. Given the challenging consumer backdrop, we look for near-term demand to remain subdued, though we are encouraged by the move in net pricing. Factoring in cost reduction initiatives, we believe WHR is positioned to largely offset volume deleverage, and model the North American major domestic appliance segment operating margin down only 14bps YOY in 2025 to \(6.4\%\) , with 3Q off 103bps YOY to \(6.3\%\) .

Unchanged vs Recent: Holidays: On average, list prices increased \(4.3\%\) , compared to \(0.1\%\) a year ago and \(+4.1\%\) YOY at Fourth of July. This was led by LG, up an average of \(14.8\%\) YOY with \(83\%\) of SKUs higher while Electrolux fell \(1.6\%\) on average, with declines across \(15\%\) of items. On a two- year stack, industry prices grew \(4.3\%\) with \(41\%\) of SKUs higher YOY vs \(7\%\) a year ago. We highlight the potential for further gains over the coming quarters as steel and
Market cap: \(\) 5.2\(bn Enterprise value:\) \ \(10.9bn 3m ADTV:\) \ \(144.5m United States Americas Homebuilders & Building Products M&A Rank: 3

other inputs adjust to trade actions, though we expect producers will respond to weaker demand with promotions if necessary.

Inventories Improve vs Fourth of July: Home Depot had the least out- of- stock items among surveyed retailers while Looe's had the most. By manufacturer, GE had the greatest availability while LG trailed in our view, this reflects pull forward by retailers and producers ahead of announced tariffs as T- 6 appliance imports rose \(\sim 9\%\) YOY from November to June. As such, we will continue to monitor changes over the coming months.

Valuation & Risks: We are Buy rated on WHR with a \(\) 107,12\(- month price target, which is based on 8.3x our Q5 - Q8 adj. EBITDA estimate. Downside risks include: 1) increased competition should peers seek to gain market share, 2) delays or the inability to deliver on strategic initiatives, 3) increase in raw material costs and an inability to pass them through, 4) production shortages or the loss of a key supplier, 5) greater risks or uncertainties around international production, and 6) weaker consumer demand.

In order to better assess the promotional environment around Labor Day, we scanned appliance prices across three major retailers. The weighted- average discount of \(24\%\) was 150bps higher vs 2024 but down 102bps vs Fourth of July. We note there was a 496bps variation among brands, narrower than 700bps last year. Samsung was the most promotional at \(27\%\) , up 19bps YOY, while Electrolux was the least at \(22\%\) , off 69bps YOY. We note Whirlpool discounts were down 7bps YOY to \(23\%\) . Our findings suggest activity is consistent with seasonality as retailers look to move volumes against a weak consumer backdrop. Looking out, we expect promotions will hold within pre- pandemic norms even as select manufacturers balance elevated inventories and inflation.
Exhibit 1: Average Discount on Top Selling Appliances by Brand
Source: www.bestbuy.com, www.homedepot.com, www.lowes.com, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

By category, freezers were the least discounted at \(17\%\) , increasing 337bps YOY, while ranges were the most at \(28\%\) , up 182bps vs last year, as discretionary demand and larger ticket remodels remain depressed. As such, we expect mix headwinds to persist, with company- specific initiatives the key differentiator. This includes our forecast for price/mix will be positive in the back half of 2025 for Whirlpool as recently launched products gain momentum. We note the company is transitioning \(30+\) % of the North America MDA portfolio this year, the largest in its history.
Exhibit 2: Average Discount by Manufacturer and Product Category

RefrigeratorWasherDryerRangesDishwasherFreezerAverageSams ung29%30%25%30%22%22%27%LG24%29%23%27%28%16%26%GE30%27%23%22%34%9%24%Electrolux26%21%19%32%15%18%22%Whirlpool23%16%20%31%22%25%23%Average26%25%22%28%24%17%24%
Average discount of best-selling appliances by brand for each T-6 category
Source: www.bestbuy.com, www.homedepot.com, www.lowes.com, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Our scans indicate list prices rose an average of \(4.3\%\) YOY vs \(- 0.1\%\) last year and \(+4.1\%\) YOY at Fourth of July. The range of \(- 1.6\%\) to \(+14.8\%\) across brands is consistent with the \(- 2.2\%\) to \(+15.2\%\) over Fourth of July, with \(41\%\) of SKUs seeing an increase vs \(7\%\) a year ago. By manufacturer, this was led by LG, up \(14.8\%\) with \(83\%\) of products higher, while Electrolux trailed at \(- 1.6\%\) with declines across \(15\%\) of items.
Exhibit 3: List Price Changes, YOY by Brand
Average list price increases on comparable best-selling appliances by brand for each T-6 category
Source: www.bestbuy.com, www.homedepot.com, www.lowes.com, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 4: Average List Price Changes YOY
Average list price increases on comparable best-selling appliances by brand for each T-6 category
Source: www.bestbuy.com, www.homedepot.com, www.lowes.com, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Given diverging strategies around changes in list and promotional prices, we also consider net pricing. We find the net industry price grew 223bps YOY at Labor Day vs \(+354\) bps YOY at Fourth of July and \(+79\) bps a year ago, with the seq. decline largely reflecting tougher comparisons. This was led by LG up 973bps YOY, while Electrolux was down 70bps YOY. Whirlpool rose roughly in line with the average at \(+199\) bps, but down from \(+420\) bps at Fourth of July largely due to tougher comparisons as we anniversary Spring 2024 actions. Given our expectations raw material costs will stay fairly stable along with promotions, we forecast net pricing (ex- FX) for Whirlpool's North America MDA segment up \(1.1\%\) YOY in 2025. That said, we see the potential for lower realizations should changes in tariffs reduce cost pressures or demand further weakens.
Exhibit 5: Net Industry Price Continues to Move Higher Through 2025Net Prices, YOY Change
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Prices for key commodity inputs to appliances have seen diverging trends YTD given cross currents between tariffs and a decelerating macro backdrop. That said, futures curves and industry forecasts suggest a normalization in commodity prices through the fall.

Against this backdrop, we model raw material costs to be roughly neutral for Whirlpool this year, in line with mgmt's expectations. We also look for the net pricing actions highlighted above along with \(\) 235\mathrm{mn}\$ from cost reduction efforts to offset higher operating costs, volume deleverage and \(\sim 150\) bps margin impact from tariffs. As such, we estimate the 2025 consolidated adj. EBIT margin will expand 39bps YOY to \(5.7\%\) Steel and resins each account for \(8 - 9\%\) of COGS, while logistics are \(10\%\)
We provide more details around the key cost inputs below.

US hot rolled steel is trading at \(\) 810\(/ton, up\) 14\% \(YTD and\) 12\% \(above a year ago. However, this is down\) 10\% \(from early June as production and demand stabilized post the impact of Section 232 tariffs. That said, our US steel team expects current prices to hold over the balance of the year, averaging\) \ \(825\) /ton in 4Q given the macro backdrop, with potential upside should visibility on trade policy improve or if interest rate cuts drive incremental demand.
Exhibit 6: US Steel Prices, YOY Change
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Following a rally earlier this year, resin prices moved lower through the summer with polyethylene and propylene down \(13\%\) and \(32\%\) YOY, respectively, given macro economic uncertainty. With this, prices are now \(47\%\) and \(61\%\) below summer 2021, respectively, per Chemical Market Analytics. Looking out, our chemicals team expects PE prices to hold flat in the near- term.
Exhibit 7: North American Resin Prices, YOY Change
Source: Chemical Market Analytics, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Spot dry- van freight rates (including fuel surcharges) are \(4\%\) off their April lows through late August as macro concerns moderated. That said, they are down \(11\%\) YTD, while

contract rates are up. Looking out, our transportation team expects spot rates (ex. fuel) will recover over the remainder of the year, largely on easing comparisons but also as trucking capacity continues to exit the market. In turn, they model spot and contract rates up low- to mid- single digits YOY. Additionally, ocean freight rates have moderated YOY post the tariff- related pull- forward as trade uncertainty is partially offset by rising capacity.
Exhibit 8: Dry-Van Rates (Incl. Fuel Surcharge), YOY Change
Source: Truckstop.com, Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Any such trading strategies are distinct from and do not affect the analyst's fundamental equity rating for such stocks, which rating reflects a stock's return potential relative to its coverage universe as described herein.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial products), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
